@ahoenselaar sorry for letting this sit.

I want to get this in and I think it's helpful, but unfortunately I'll be a bit longer before being able to review
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.

OK thanks for the confirmation.

So while I understand that you are abusing the override feature in a way
that is safe (from the security standpoint but not completely from the
semantics standpoint), I am worried that this distinction will be lost on
the majority of gRPC users that will have a look at this code.
That's another way to say that I am concerned about having this code
checked-in as part of the gRPC distrib. The goal though will be to have TLS
bindings that are compatible with spiffe and  would allow you to implement
the semantics that you want, and this we will do in the gRPC repo.
In the meantime, if you need this feature (even in a hackish state), it
seems to me that you can completely drive it from application code.

Does that make sense to you?

On Thu, Jun 15, 2017 at 4:29 PM, Augusto Roman <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> *@augustoroman* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In examples/ruby/mutual_auth/client.rb
> <https://github.com/grpc/grpc/pull/10529#discussion_r122217088>:
>
> > +  certs = load_test_certs
> +  GRPC::Core::ChannelCredentials.new(certs[0], certs[1], certs[2])
> +end
> +
> +def main
> +  host_override = 'foo.test.google.fr'
> +  OptionParser.new do |opts|
> +    opts.on('--server_host_override HOST_OVERRIDE',
> +	    'override the SSL target host name.') do |v|
> +      host_override = v
> +    end
> +  end.parse!
> +
> +  # NEVER override the target hostname in a production environment. In
> +  # production, the FQDN of the server and the name in the certificate have to
> +  # match.
>
> Yes, that's what we're doing. Thanks for the SAN and spiffe pointers,
> that's very informative!
>
> â€”

Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.

Thanks @jboeuf, yes that makes sense and I'm happy to learn about spiffe and that sounds like a good path forward. I agree that the subtleties involved in doing what we're doing should not be considered general advice since it's applicable only to narrow, specific use case and abuses the semantics of the certificates.
@augustoroman Thanks much for your understanding. I'll let @apolcyn continue with the review with this guideline in mind as I'm going on vacation tonight.
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.

We found a Contributor License Agreement for you (the sender of this pull request), but were unable to find agreements for the commit author(s).  If you authored these, maybe you used a different email address in the git commits than was used to sign the CLA ([login here](https://cla.developers.google.com/) to double check)?  If these were authored by someone else, then they will need to sign a CLA as well, and confirm that they're okay with these being contributed to Google.
In order to pass this check, please resolve this problem and have the pull request author add another comment and the bot will run again.

So there's good news and bad news.

:thumbsup: The good news is that everyone that needs to sign a CLA (the pull request submitter and all commit authors) have done so.  Everything is all good there.

:confused: The bad news is that it appears that one or more commits were authored by someone other than the pull request submitter.  We need to confirm that they're okay with their commits being contributed to this project.  Please have them confirm that here in the pull request.

*Note to project maintainer: This is a terminal state, meaning the `cla/google` commit status will not change from this state. It's up to you to confirm consent of the commit author(s) and merge this pull request when appropriate.*

<!-- need_author_consent -->

CLAs look good, thanks!

<!-- ok -->
Updated based on your comments. PTAL

@ahoenselaar after some thought, I have to follow the concern mentioned by @jboeuf about the overriding of the server name in a sort of official example.

On the other hand, I'd love to add this in is as an end-to-end test for grpc-ruby, (by converting it into an rspec test and fitting it in with the rest of the tests).

If you'd like to go down that route, I have a couple of notes:

* All of the content here could probably be placed under a new directory under the `src/ruby/spec` directory of this repo. Maybe `src/ruby/spec/client_server_auth`.

* Probably add the `openssl` gem as a development dependency in [here](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/grpc.gemspec#L33)

* We should probably convert the protobuf types here to use [these generated protobufs](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/tree/master/src/ruby/pb/src/proto/grpc/testing)

  * those protobuf could  be `required` in the test file similarly as is done in [this test](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/ruby/pb/test/client.rb#L40)

Since this is using security features that are intended for tests, IMO this would fit best if it was just a test itself (docs and helpful pointers could still refer to it).

PLMK if this sounds ok to do.

thanks for the content so far.
Thanks for your pull request. The automated tests will run as soon as one of the admins verifies this change is ok for us to run on our infrastructure.
